page.title: 18The River Avon at Hanham.
page.content: The River Avon,below Hanham Court is popular for recreation.There are two pubs which overlook the lock and weir and are stops for boat trips from Bristol Docks.The area is also called Hanham Mills because it was the site of a corn or grist mill for over 800 years,probably built by the monks of Keynsham Abbey.Londonderry Wharf,once known as "Jacky Whites"is further down river towards Bath. Rings were set into the walls of Bath stone for mooring. It is now hard to trace the course of the sidings except where the branch rose to join the Avon Wharf line near Willsbridge where earthworks are clear.Horse drawn wagons and trains would have transported coal to barges where it could be shipped around England.Now it is used as a picnic spot. by Clare,Emma and John (aged 13)
